sheets.Sheet1.name: Cristiano Ronaldo
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Ronaldo's year

Probably the best compliment of all is that he has beaten one of the giants of his sport into second place. Lionel Messi has taken the art of attacking football to its highest level, to the point at which it is perfectly legitimate to compare his achievement to Diego Maradona’s. Yet Cristiano Ronaldo has caught, and maybe overtaken, him as the most destructive force in world football. Ronaldo doesn’t just take on opposition defences, he bludgeons them. He could score the kind of goal that George Best used to score. But then again, he could score the kind of goal that Nat Lofthouse used to score. And he could score the kind of goal that the other Ronaldo used to score. It’s a blur of speed, gelled hair and fluorescent boots and perhaps the greatest part of it all is that this is a workaholic’s career. For all his natural skill and athleticism, it gets overlooked sometimes that Ronaldo is utterly devoted to his craft. He is coming up for 30, but just try to find the first sign of decline when he is greedily accumulating goals at the prodigious rate we have seen over the past year. Ronaldo is the former Manchester United star who was clapped off by an Anfield crowd this season. It is known as authentic greatness.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Lionel Messi
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Messi's year

At the time of writing Lionel Messi had played 50 games for Barcelona in 2014 and scored 48 goals. He had hit the post 11 times, too, so that figure could be even higher, and he had provided 19 assists. He ends the year having just become the all-time leading scorer in La Liga and the all-time leading scorer in European competition. And that’s just for his club: he also took Argentina to the World Cup final. And yet most people have concluded that this was a bad year for Messi, which perhaps it was. It was certainly disappointing for his club, runners-up to Atlético Madrid in the league, Real Madrid in the cup and beaten by Atlético in the Champions League quarter-finals. The statistics really just hammer home the absurdly high standards Messi had set. It was a difficult season off the pitch as well as on it, with injury and tax issues, while Messi’s relationship with some on the board has been strained. Meanwhile his team fades too. In a way, maybe the surprise is that he played as well as he did, albeit still not well enough to top this chart. For some Messi is the best player of all time, but not the best player in the world in 2014: Messi slips off the top of the Guardian list for the first time. Only nine of our 73 judges ranked him as the world’s best player in 2014.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Manuel Neuer
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Neuer's year

Neuer has politely rebuffed the idea that he has revolutionised goalkeeping, pointing at the influence of Jens Lehmann and Edwin van der Sar. But there is little doubt that the 28-year-old has set a new benchmark by adapting with particular brilliance to the modern demands on the position. His confidence, skill and pace allow him to come out of his area and effectively give his teams a 12th player on the pitch; Neuer is both No1 and last defender, an additional safety barrier behind the high line and an extra outlet for passes to break the opposition pressing. “Only Franz Beckenbauer was a better sweeper,” said Germany’s goalkeeping coach, Andreas Köpke, after Neuer had run six kilometres and touched the ball 21 times outside his own box in the last-16 match against Algeria at the World Cup, during which he also saved 85% of all shots on goal. His game can look flash to the uninitiated but Neuer, who has studied the movement of handball and ice hockey goalkeepers for inspiration, says he is simply doing what is best for his sides. “Goalkeepers can’t do their own thing and wait to make a great save on the line anymore,” he has said. “They are team players. Behind everything is the fundamental question: What does the team need?"
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Arjen Robben
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Robben's year

There has often been a resistance to the charm of Arjen Robben in the past, a sense that his almost self-parodying fondness for hitting the deck has undermined his appeal, but he is finally winning acceptance from the wider public. A rare case of a winger who appears to be getting better and more consistent with age, the level the Dutchman reached for club and country this year has seen him rise 10 places on this list and although Robben has just missed out on a place on the podium, it is heartening to see recognition of his talent. Life would be easier if he stayed on his feet a bit more but even his detractors would have to admit that few things are more exhilarating than Robben on the run, snaking inside from the right and bending a shot into the far corner with his left foot. He can be selfish, but the brilliance of Robben is such that his intentions are often predictable and yet defences still cannot stop him. Robben was exceptional for Bayern Munich as they won the Bundesliga and a leader for Holland on their way to finishing third in Brazil. His performance when Holland destroyed Spain 5-1 was one for the ages.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Thomas Müller
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Müller's year

“I don’t think there are many [opposition] players in the world who understand his runs and ideas,” Bastian Schweinsteiger recently said of Thomas Müller’s unorthodox playing style. With his spindly legs and sloppy attire – socks pulled halfway down, singlet peaking out above his backside – the Bayern Munich and Germany forward does a very good job at masking his predatory prowess. “There are others who are better in the air, better with their right, better with their left,” he has admitted. His deliberate free-kick stumble against Algeria didn’t quite work out but he still scored five goals for the Nationalmannschaft in Brazil to double his tally in final tournaments. Still only 25, he is on course to outscore both his namesake Gerd Müller (14 goals in the World Cup) and the current record-holder Miroslav Klose (16). Müller has moaned that “muscles don’t grow” on him but also credited that deficit for forcing him to be more proficient above the neckline, to explore spaces others don’t even begin to see. “My legs have helped me,” he told Süddeutsche Zeitung. “If you can’t just count on your physical attributes, you have to switch on your brain and make certain runs to avoid getting tackled.”
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Luis Suárez
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Suárez's year

A typical year in the career of one of football’s most instinctive, divisive, brilliant and troubled talents. The striker inspired Liverpool to the cusp of their first league title for 24 years, his 31 league goals, audacious skill and relentless movement integral to the breathtaking form of Brendan Rodgers’ team. Suárez swept up England’s individual honours, being named PFA and FWA Player of the Year despite claims that everyone had it in for him, with an apparent new-found maturity behind his elevation into the game’s elite. Liverpool’s title challenge ended in tears but the World Cup offered another chance to alter his reputation. Recovering from a knee ligament injury to score twice against England was a fairytale for Uruguay’s talismanic forward, but five days later he blew it, or bit it, by sinking his teeth into Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini. His World Cup was over in disgrace. Fifa hit Suárez with a four-month ban from all football-related activity and a nine-match international suspension but the record punishment did not deter Barcelona from signing the striker for £75m in July. He has made a slow start at the Camp Nou but left behind a gaping hole at Anfield.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Neymar
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Neymar's year

Brazil’s wobbly World Cup train derailed even before the dramatic Germany game. Until Juan Zuñiga’s challenge literally broke Neymar’s back, the striker had carried the host country on his young shoulders. Despite almost unbearable pressure to be Brazil’s hero, he scored two goals in the opening game against Croatia after the host nation had fallen behind and were struggling to find their rhythm. There were another two goals in the last group game against Cameroon before the win on penalties against Chile and then that fateful game against Colombia in Fortaleza. With 42 goals, Neymar is already the fifth-highest scorer in the history of the Seleção and with seven more will pip a certain Zico for fourth place. His record for Barcelona is not bad either: in his first 18 matches for the Blaugrana in 2014-15 Neymar scored 14 goals, three of them in the Champions League. It did help that from his first day in Catalonia Neymar did not try to upstage Lionel Messi, instead happily assuming second-fiddle duties. Getting more adapted to the rigours of European football will only make Neymar more dangerous, and all of a sudden the possibility of having to do without Messi is not completely unthinkable for Barcelona fans.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Gareth Bale
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Bale's year

After an injury-plagued start to his career as Real Madrid’s €100m record signing, Bale showed no sign of wilting under the burden of his price tag. He began 2014 in fine style and finished his first season in Spain with 22 goals, including one solo effort in the Copa del Rey final that was as breathtaking as it was lung-bursting. He also became the first Welshman to score in a Champions League final, during Real’s extra-time victory over Atlético. Bale has started this season as he finished the last, while speculation that his presence at the Bernabéu might pose a threat to the ego of Cristiano Ronaldo has proved to be without foundation. Indeed, the pair seem to have hit it off – “He understands me, I understand him and he produces fantastic passes,” enthused the Portuguese, “I love him.” Bale speaks equally highly of his team-mate. “I think I’m improving all the time and trying to get to the level that Cristiano’s at,” he said. “It gives me that platform to aim for and keeps me improving and hopefully one day I can get there.” On the international front, Bale’s nationality precluded him from strutting his stuff on the World Cup stage, but thanks to his influence Wales are entertaining realistic hopes of reaching the finals of Euro 2016.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Philipp Lahm
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Lahm's year

The Germany and Bayern stalwart successfully filled in as a deep-lying playmaker for Sami Khedira and Bastian Schweinsteiger at the start of the World Cup, bringing rhythm as well as defensive stability to midfield. Joachim Löw switched him back to his customary right-back role from the quarter-final against France onwards, and the 31-year-old went on to lead his side to a fourth World Cup triumph, shedding a few tears at the final whistle at the Maracanã. Has there ever been a captain who has played two different positions so successfully in a major tournament? “A footballing robot,” the former Mainz coach Thomas Tuchel called him; Pep Guardiola praised him as “the most intelligent player I’ve ever worked with”. Lahm retired from the national team after lifting the trophy. Guardiola has had him playing in yet another role this season, as an inside-right midfielder with a licence to go forward. Lahm duly scored two goals in the league before suffering a broken ankle in training in November. “We cannot play badly any more,” he said. “That’s mostly due to the  manager, and the variety we now have in our game.” In other words: Bayern have now become a side in his image.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Sergio Agüero
sheets.Sheet1.profile:
In video: members of our expert panel discuss Agüero's year

Sergio Agüero scored 19 goals in his first 21 appearances in a season that - injury permitting - is shaping to be the finest of his Manchester City career. For a man pivotal in both City’s Premier League title triumphs this is some achievement, and points to how Agüero has again elevated his game to a new level. Manuel Pellegrini, Samir Nasri and a host of other City players bill him as marginally a class down from Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi and, considering the form the 26-year-old had consistently showed before he was sidelined by a knee injury in early December, it is difficult to argue with that view. The hope now is that Agüero can recover soon and instantly return to the player who – when Pellegrini’s side had a prolonged wobble – kept City in the Premier League title chase and the Champions League almost single-handedly. Who can forget that nerveless hat-trick against Bayern? Agüero featured in five of Argentina’s games as they reached the World Cup final but was not quite able to reproduce his club form on the biggest stage of all. He started the final on the bench but came on at half-time for Ezequiel Lavezzi but was unable to prevent Germany taking the prize.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Toni Kroos
sheets.Sheet1.profile: During the World Cup Johan Cruyff described Kroos’s play as “nearly perfect”. Statistically that view was backed up as Kroos was ranked top of all the players in Brazil last summer (earning a mark of 9.79 out of 10) on metrics based on passing, tackles, ground covered and goals. Real Madrid were delighted to have procured the services of such a refined modern midfielder from Bayern. His classy technique is welded onto his physical fitness – the feat of featuring in 90 games for club and country in the last 18 months was based on a programme of looking after himself extremely well. Kroos had a superb 2014.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Diego Costa
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A brute of a forward whose nomadic career through Portuguese and Spanish football finally found fulfilment last season at Atlético Madrid. His 35-goal tally took Diego Simeone’s fine team to the Primera Liga title and a Champions League final, where he was hamstrung and unable to contribute. Fitness issues then went on to hamper his impact for his adopted country, Spain, at the World Cup but, as a £32m Chelsea player, he then scored seven times in his first four Premier League fixtures. The focal point of José Mourinho’s side, he boasts the physical presence and aggression to thrive in English football, and looks set to do exactly that.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Zlatan Ibrahimovic
sheets.Sheet1.profile: “A World Cup without me is not worth watching,” lamented Zlatan after his dream was dashed following a play-off with Cristiano Ronaldo’s Portugal. It speaks volumes for the global status of the singular Swede that an internet campaign “VemIbra” (Come here, Ibra), which included the likes of Ronaldo, Rai, Bebeto and loads of locals imploring him to go, went viral. The Swede made it to Brazil in the end, if only as a spectator. Now aged 33, he may be towards the end of his pomp, but he is still a potent marksman and inspiration for Paris Saint-Germain. He was the top scorer in France last season as PSG retained the league title.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Ángel Di María
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Described by our La Liga correspondent, Sid Lowe, as the kind of player Real Madrid might have signed last year if they had not already got him, Ángel Di María was the stand-out performer in the Spanish side’s Champions League final win over their city rivals Atlético. One of the players of the tournament at the World Cup, where Argentina lost the final in their winger’s absence through injury, his summer move to Manchester United for a British record transfer fee of £59.7m has thus far been an unequivocal success. Quick, intelligent and blessed with great technique, “Fideo” moves up 58 places from last year’s 72.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: James Rodríguez
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The highest new entry on this year’s list, the Colombian figured in the top 10 of just over a third of our 73 judges. It was always likely that Real Madrid would use the World Cup as a kind of casting for their latest galáctico. They needed a new star to emerge and none did so more than James Rodríguez. Hardly a nobody – after all, he had cost £38.5m a year ago – ‘Hames’ was still a revelation in Brazil. Top goalscorer and scorer, against Uruguay, of the tournament’s top goal too. He has performed superbly since joining Madrid, with Carlo Ancelotti finding a role for him despite the absence of an obvious natural position in the lineup
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Eden Hazard
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Hazard has long been considered one of the most talented midfielders of his generation but has also been known to frustrate. Since returning to Stamford Bridge José Mourinho has prodded him constantly to try to make him more efficient. “It is the first time I have known this with a coach,” admitted Hazard. “The others tended to protect me. He really wants my potential to explode.” Hazard is not as influential as he should be for his country, as the World Cup proved, but he has become far more consistent for Chelsea – he was their leading assist-provider last season, though he is lagging well behind Cesc Fàbregas so far this season.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Thibaut Courtois
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Excellent over three seasons as a key member of Diego Simeone’s triumphant Atlético Madrid side before returning to his parent club, Courtois has slipped seamlessly into life in the Premier League at Chelsea. Commanding and authoritative, even at 22, and a formidable presence albeit with a slender frame, he is the natural successor to Petr Cech and is already established as the club’s No1 having signed a new contract in September. His progress has been just as smooth with the Belgian national team, for whom he is first choice and played a major part in ensuring progress into the World Cup quarter-finals.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Yaya Touré
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Touré’s PR was poor this year, his birthday cake outburst attracting ridicule and leading some people to dismiss him as a sulk when he made a slow start to the latest Premier League season, with some perhaps not taking sufficient account of the impact on Touré of the death of one of his brothers from cancer just before the World Cup. On the pitch the three-time and reigning African player of the year has been in better form of late, raising hopes that he is returning to the extraordinary standard that he set last season, when he was one of the most dominant midfielders in the world and plundered 20 Premier League goals.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Karim Benzema
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Maybe he does not score as many as you would expect for a Real Madrid No9 but there should be no doubt about Karim Benzema’s importance to his club. His selfless leading of the line makes Madrid click in attack and his ego-free, intelligent movement creates the space for Cristiano Ronaldo and Gareth Bale to spread havoc in opposition defences. Benzema was once a source of frustration but he is hugely appreciated now that he is fully applying himself. He was slightly disappointing when France lost their World Cup quarter-final to Germany, but was nevertheless named as the French player of the year, for the third time.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Paul Pogba
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Still just 21 years old, Pogba has established himself over the last year as one of the most influential figures in a Juventus team that continues to dominate Italian football. A genuine box-to-box midfielder – as demonstrated by a lung-bursting charge from the edge of his own area to tame a cross and score against Lazio in November – he was the only Serie A player to be included on Fifa’s 23-man Ballon d’Or shortlist, and is the second-highest new entry on our list. The scary part is that both his club and national team managers believe he has room to improve.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Xabi Alonso
sheets.Sheet1.profile: There was, perhaps, a sense that last season was the beginning of the end for Alonso. His partnership in the centre of midfield with Luka Modric was crucial in providing a base for Real Madrid’s success in the Champions League (although he missed the final through suspension), but, with the club happy to release him, a poor World Cup hinted that his powers were beginning to wane. Not a bit of it. He’s had a new lease of life since joining Bayern Munich and is now the passing hub at the centre of one of the two stand-out club sides in Europe.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Alexis Sánchez
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Arsène Wenger is of the opinion that most of the world’s top strikers nowadays come from South America. It’s the “street fighting” qualities he admires, and Sánchez plays with a souped-up verve that brings such energy to the game. He dazzled at the World Cup for Chile, and it was Arsenal’s stroke of luck that Barcelona, needing to make room in their front line to enable their pursuit of Liverpool’s Luis Suárez, decided that Sánchez was expendable. His outstanding start to life in the Premier League – with 10 goals and five assists in his first 15 appearances – has been a shining light during a sticky period for Arsenal.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Luka Modric
sheets.Sheet1.profile: In Luka Modric’s first season in Madrid, an online poll asked supporters to vote for the season’s worst signings. Modric came out on top. It was absurd then; it looks even more ridiculous now. Having finally forgotten the flawed idea that he had to play just off the forwards, fans and critics have embraced him as a central midfielder who controls and creates, leading Madrid’s evolution in style on the way to a 10th European Cup. Few players shrug off pressure so easily: a quick pass and suddenly the horizon is clear. His year ends disappointingly, with a thigh injury, sustained while playing for Croatia in November, ruling him out for three months.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Mario Götze
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A versatile midfielder who looks at home on either wing, playing as a false nine or in his favoured role as a No10, Götze secured his place in football folklore in the World Cup final by scoring the winning goal in extra time. Summoned from the bench shortly before the end of normal time with instructions from his manager to “show the world you are better than Messi and can decide the World Cup”, his stylish strike certainly denied his Argentinian counterpart, though it would take rather a leap to suggest that makes Götze the better player. While there is no shame in not being quite as good as Messi, the feeling remains that there is still plenty more to come from a 22-year-old who, as ridiculous as it might sound, has yet to fulfil his obvious potential despite having pretty much already won it all with club and country. Having initially been a starter he was a bit-part player for the latter stages of the World Cup, while he was also a peripheral figure on the fringes of the Bayern first team last season. We can only conclude that it was his World Cup final heroics that moved him up rather than down in these rankings. Now an established and presumably more trusted regular in Pep Guardiola’s Bayern Munich side, it again seems fitting to conclude his pen picture with the sentiment: one feels this is just the beginning.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Bastian Schweinsteiger
sheets.Sheet1.profile: This was the year that Schweinsteiger collected his seventh Bundesliga title for an imperious Bayern side (nobody has ever won more than eight), helped Germany win the World Cup and was named as his country’s captain for the 2016 European Championship campaign. “Bastian is an absolute leader,” Joachim Löw said in September. “He unites all players behind him.” And yet it was also a year in which his influence arguably diminished, as injuries interrupted his playing time. But when he did play he radiated intelligence and passing acumen. “He is a strategist – you feel his presence,” says Manuel Neuer.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Franck Ribéry
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The French winger, a contender for the Ballon D’Or in 2013 having finished mightily close to the conventional top two of Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi in the voting, has suffered an injury-dogged year. It was a big personal blow for him to miss the World Cup with a back problem – at the age of 31 he is far from certain to be part of the scene in four years’ time. The fitness issues have seen him slip from fourth in last year’s Guardian Top 100 to 26th. Having returned as recently as October, he has recovered some strong form and scored his 100th goal for Bayern against Bayer Leverkusen earlier this month, in his 288th game.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Javier Mascherano
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Very well liked and commands enormous respect, not least because he talks about the game with depth and intelligence, but in truth his club season was a disappointing one, as Mascherano admitted. Then the Little Chief helped lead Argentina to the World Cup final in a position he has not occupied for his club for as long as anyone could remember and things fell into place. So good as a deep midfielder that in Catalonia people at last began to ask: “Hey, this Mascherano bloke, how about not playing him at centre-back?” Tellingly, Neymar recently revealed that his Ballon d’Or votes went to Messi, Ronaldo – and Mascherano.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Andrés Iniesta
sheets.Sheet1.profile: By his own lofty standards it’s been a disappointing year for the metronomic Barcelona and Spain passing machine, who drops 23 places from his top-five spot last year. Iniesta has endured one of those rare calendar years in which he has failed to win a trophy and was also forced to endure the ignominy of playing every minute of Spain’s hideous World Cup defence, after the high of winning the previous tournament in South Africa and scoring the final’s only goal. For all that, the 30-year-old from Fuentealbilla is nothing if not resilient and looks set to continue to conduct the Barcelona orchestra for some time yet.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Andrea Pirlo
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Pirlo had more to lose than most from Juventus’s change of manager this summer: Antonio Conte’s successor, Massimiliano Allegri, had deemed the midfielder surplus to requirements at Milan just three years previously. But the coach knew better than to repeat his mistakes, and has kept Pirlo at the heart of his team. Although the player’s performances have been inconsistent this season, his vision and range of passing continue to mark him apart. There are few in the world who can strike a free-kick more cleanly, and Pirlo has lately reminded us, such as with the winner against Torino, that he can score from open play, too.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Robert Lewandowski
sheets.Sheet1.profile: It has been a challenging 2014 for Lewandowski, who has dropped 12 places from his 2013 ranking. He was the consummate professional when seeing out an awkward final six months of his contract at Borussia Dortmund, and has now had to adapt from being the man around whom a team was built to working in one full of superstars. His start in Munich has been solid if unspectacular but he has endured worse, having found his first six months in Dortmund in 2010 immensely frustrating as he struggled to break into the side. Continues to score regularly, and has the all-round game and mental toughness to succeed.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Thiago Silva
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Few players went into 2014 under as much pressure as the captain of Brazil. His performances at the World Cup were not as assured as usual but the team completely unravelled when he was suspended for the ill-fated match against Germany. He had gone into that tournament on the back of a successful club campaign, helping PSG to another league title and a strong showing in the Champions League, but this season has so far been below his normal high standards. His manager, Laurent Blanc, has suggested the player has not yet got over the World Cup ordeal, which may not be surprising given he now partners David Luiz at club level too.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Sergio Ramos
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Quite apart from his tenacious defensive qualities, the Spaniard’s excellence from set pieces (at both ends of the pitch) has never been as critical as in this year’s Champions League final. Having scored twice in the away leg of the semi-final at Bayern Munich to put that result beyond doubt, Real’s search for La Décima was in peril as they trailed their city rivals Atlético in stoppage time of the final in Lisbon, until Ramos powered Luka Modic’s corner past Thibaut Courtois with a trademark header. It was the catalyst for pandemonium, extra time, and history. Ramos recently celebrated his 300th appearance for Real Madrid.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Arturo Vidal
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Troubled by a persistent knee injury and criticised by the press after getting caught up in a nightclub scuffle in October, following a fine World Cup Vidal has not endured the happiest of starts to the new Serie A season. His performances on the pitch have suffered, falling short of the high standards he set in previous campaigns. But Vidal remains an exceptional player, a muscular, ball-winning midfielder who constructs as well as he destroys. He even chips in with his share of goals, reaching double figures in each of the past two seasons. Juventus are confident that he will be back at his best before long.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Diego Godín
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Diego Godín scored the goal that clinched a first, seemingly impossible league title for Atlético Madrid since 1996, breaking up the Madrid-Barcelona stranglehold for the first time in a decade. He also scored the goal that, until the 94th minute, was on course to give Atlético Madrid an even more impossible European Cup – the first in their history. He also scored the goal that put Uruguay through against Italy at the World Cup, only for Luis Suárez to steal all the attention. Oh, and he defended brilliantly too, game after game after game. His astonishing performances merited a place on the Ballon d’Or shortlist.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: David Silva
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Along with Sergio Agüero, the Spaniard is rated as the supreme footballer at City by his peers, a master of both ball and time who turns contests with a feint, precise pass, or jinking run. One charge against the 28-year-old is that he does not score enough goals, managing only two for his club this season at the time of writing – a disappointing return for a player who glides around games with such control. This may be a factor in Silva slipping three places in our list, as he scored a total of nine club goals in 2013, compared with just five so far in 2014. He did not have a good World Cup, although no member of the Spain squad excelled in Brazil.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Cesc Fàbregas
sheets.Sheet1.profile: With his surging midfield runs and perceptive passing, Cesc Fàbregas has been the creative force behind Chelsea’s assault on this season’s title race. Leading the way on Premier League assists, the Spaniard has a keen eye for a killer pass for a team that so often fired blanks last season. Playing in a deeper role than expected, the stats confirm Fàbregas has already become one of the most influential creative midfielders in Premier League history. Perhaps tellingly, he was only a bit-part player in Spain’s disastrous defence of the World Cup.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Vincent Kompany
sheets.Sheet1.profile: But for Steven Gerrard’s slip against Chelsea, Kompany could easily have been the man who lost the league for Manchester City, his late error allowing Philippe Coutinho to score the winner in their 3-2 defeat at Liverpool in April. That would have been harsh on City’s captain, though, and a sign of his resilience came when he scored in their title-clinching win over West Ham on the final day of last season. He has not been quite as dominant so far during this campaign, but you only need to look at the panic in City’s defence whenever he is missing through injury or suspension to see how highly Kompany is valued.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Arda Turan
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The bearded 27-year-old from Fatih became the first Turkish-born player to be presented with a La Liga winners’ medal after he proved instrumental in Atlético Madrid’s unexpected march to the title. A right-footed winger who usually plays on the left, Turan is renowned for his speed, close control and ability to take on and beat full-backs. He can also cross and takes a mean corner, while goals against Real Madrid and Juventus this season suggest that he is also a man for the big occasion. Has yet to shine consistently on the international stage for Turkey, however, who failed to qualify for the World Cup.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Mats Hummels
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Many people believe that defending is becoming a lost art but that is not an accusation that can be levelled at Mats Hummels, whose performances for Germany at the World Cup were exemplary. He even scored the winner in the quarter-final against France and his performances were marked by the unflappability of his defending and also by how accomplished he was on the ball, making him a very modern centre-back. Perhaps the only reason he is not higher on the list is because injuries mean we have not seen more of him for Borussia Dortmund. They are a different side when Hummels is fit.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Marco Reus
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Brazil might not have felt lucky this year but consider this: they might have lost by more than 7-1 if an ankle injury had not prevented Marco Reus from taking part in the World Cup. Reus had played a big role in Germany’s qualification, contributing five goals and three assists in six matches, before being denied the chance to grace the global stage. That injury, and several others, have hampered his club career too and go some way towards explaining Dortmund’s struggles. His standing remains so high, however, that virtually every top club in Europe hopes he chooses them if, as expected, he leaves next summer.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Carlos Tevez
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Omitted from Argentina’s World Cup squad despite scoring 19 goals in his first Serie A season with Juventus, Tevez has responded by coming back even stronger. Afforded greater freedom to drop deep and roam behind the attack for his club side, Tevez ended a five-year Champions League scoring drought in September and served up a Diego Maradona-esque goal against Parma in November, dribbling from his own half to the edge of the opposition area before finishing into the bottom corner. In between the two he was recalled to the Argentina national team by the new manager, Gerardo Martino. Better late than never.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Koke
sheets.Sheet1.profile: At half-time in Spain’s match against Chile at the World Cup, Vicente del Bosque sent on Jorge Resurrección, or “Koke”, as he is better known. As it turned out, there would be no resurrection in Brazil but Koke is the man who will be expected to lead one now. He will be the creative fulcrum at the heart of the Spain midfield as they begin the post-Xavi era. A European Under-21 champion in 2013, his responsibility is growing. It is not just Spain either: Barcelona tried to sign Koke in the summer as they too embarked on the process of replacing Xavi, only to find that Atlético were not prepared to sell and Koke, who has come up through the club’s youth system and is an Atlético fan, was not prepared to push for a departure. For some, Koke’s introduction into the Spain team should have come sooner.  He was coming off the back of a superb season in which he was the most important creative player for the surprise league champions and had been vitally important in Europe too: his goal saw Atlético beat Barcelona in the quarter-finals. Last season, only Ángel Di María provided more assists in the Spanish league; so far this season, no one has provided more. His evolution is still ongoing. He reads the game well and passes impeccably, but he mostly played in a right-sided midfield role for Atlético last season, rather than in the middle; now he alternates and plays occasional games in the centre. Koke is not yet taking full control, but he soon will.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Wayne Rooney
sheets.Sheet1.profile: He broke his World Cup goalscoring duck in Brazil, he became the captain of Manchester United and England and he won his 100th international cap. Overall, it has not been a terrible year for Wayne Rooney. And yet look how low he is on this list, having slipped from No28. True, he is still England’s best player and Louis van Gaal has been able to rely on him at United, but when it comes to the elite, Rooney is no longer part of the discussion. There is a spark missing. He remains an extremely effective player, and an especially fine finisher, but is the old magic still there?
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: David Alaba
sheets.Sheet1.profile: When Bayern Munich faced Manchester United in the quarter-finals of the Champions League, Pep Guardiola used an unusual tactic: he instructed his full-backs to drift inside into central midfield positions when Bayern had possession. Philipp Lahm had already played both roles for Guardiola, but Alaba was even more comfortable with this tactic. The Austrian is a brilliant all-rounder, dynamic enough to bomb forward down the touchline, yet intelligent enough to play in midfield for a Guardiola side, and creative enough to become an outright playmaker at international level. Others receive more attention, but Alaba could be Bayern’s most complete footballer.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Robin van Persie
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Few strikers have finished with the consistency and sheer variety of Van Persie in recent years but 2014 has at times been reminiscent of his stop-start early career. Twenty-one goals in 37 appearances for club and country is a more than respectable record but he struggled with injury early in the year and, despite a return to form domestically in recent weeks, has never quite looked comfortable at the post-Ferguson Manchester United. But the old instincts remain: an astonishing header against Spain at the World Cup was a reminder that, when he is in the groove, Van Persie has the capacity to improvise in ways that nobody else can.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Oscar
sheets.Sheet1.profile: After a disappointing World Cup, in which he was rather unfairly – given how Luiz Felipe Scolari’s system curtailed his freedom to roam – singled out for criticism by the public and media, Oscar has had a pretty good 2014-15 season for Chelsea so far with three goals and five assists for José Mourinho’s team in 14 games at the time of writing. He was one of the players the new Seleção manager, Dunga, kept on board after returning to the job to pick up the pieces after the World Cup. Oscar will have to work hard to win back the fans in his homeland, but make no mistake: he is crucial for Brazil’s future.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Edinson Cavani
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Cavani’s name still seems to appear whenever a top Premier League club is linked with a centre-forward but his stock has fallen during a patchy year. After a barnstorming start to his PSG career he only scored six times between January and May, subsequently failing to impress at a World Cup where a penalty against Costa Rica was his major contribution for Uruguay. A one-in-two ratio this term has hardly been a bad return for Cavani, who is as formidable an all-rounder as they come when firing, but he is capable of better and if he and his strike partner, Zlatan Ibrahimovic, do not see eye to eye, as rumoured, it is unlikely to help his form.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Nemanja Matic
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Conventional wisdom says you should never go back, but since returning to Chelsea in January for £21m, about seven times more than his value when Benfica signed him from Chelsea three years earlier, Matic has emerged as one of the best holding players in the Premier League: mobile, tactically intelligent, a good passer of the ball and capable of making a tackle. That Chelsea’s first defeat of the season came in the first game he missed, at Newcastle, seems significant: he protects John Terry and Gary Cahill, allowing them to sit deep, and provides a platform for the more creative Cesc Fàbregas and Oscar.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Ivan Rakitić
sheets.Sheet1.profile: When Rakitic first emerged at Basel and then Schalke, he tended to be used wide on the left, but his conversion into a more central playmaker, often operating quite deep, after his move to Sevilla in 2011 was the making of him. He created 100 chances in the 2012-13 season, the fourth highest total in Europe, and then scored 13 goals and set up 17 last season as he helped Sevilla win the Europa League. At 26, he is just reaching his peak and should be ideally suited to creating chances for Barcelona’s extraordinary front three. His midfield partnership with Luka Modric has been a major factor in Croatia’s good form since the World Cup.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Xavi
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The old master seemed lost to top-level football in June, when he was strongly linked with a move from Barcelona to Qatar or Major League Soccer. However close to fruition either of those moves were, he eventually opted to stay and contribute to Luis Enrique’s quiet-ish revolution. He will be 35 in January and is being handled with care – he has not played two games in a week yet this season. The way in which his Spain career ended, with that 5-1 defeat to Holland, seemed almost unfair but another year or more of seeing this once-in-a-generation metronome on some of the biggest stages is surely cause for celebration.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Daniel Sturridge
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Has a keen eye for goal and formed a deadly partnership with Luis Suárez for Liverpool last season, scoring 21 goals in 29 Premier League appearances, although the suspicion remains that – like the rest of his team-mates – he will struggle to scale similar heights without the Uruguayan’s assistance. His goal against Italy was one of few World Cup highlights for England but a recurring thigh injury has kept him out of action since the beginning of September, leading to accusations that he is mentally weak. The longer he remains sidelined at struggling Liverpool, the more the legend of his goalscoring prowess grows.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Raheem Sterling
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The 20-year-old makes his debut in our list after a rollercoaster year in which his performances for Liverpool earned him a nomination for PFA Young Player of the Year, a call-up for England’s ill-fated expedition to the World Cup and sanctimonious tabloid opprobrium for enjoying a night out shortly after telling Roy Hodgson he felt too tired to start a Euro qualifier against Estonia. The youngest player in this year’s top 100, Sterling is a nimble winger who can also play through the centre. However, despite his talent Sterling remains a work in progress.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Branislav Ivanovic
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Strong, consistent and well-established as a key member of one of the Premier League’s more miserly back-lines. The Serb has been José Mourinho’s first-choice right-back since the manager’s return to Chelsea with the team having come to rely upon his energy on the flank, contributing in open play as well as with his spring at set-pieces. There was that winner at Manchester City in February, but it is his reliability that stands him out. Aggressive – Raheem Sterling described him as “a tank” who was his “scariest” opponent – and inspirational, he is always able to move inside to centre-half, where he features for Serbia.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Mesut Özil
sheets.Sheet1.profile: What a strange year Özil has had. He started every game as Germany won the World Cup and also helped Arsenal win the FA Cup, their first trophy since 2005. He has achieved more than most. And yet Özil’s value has been questioned because of some invisible performances for Arsenal, his cause not helped by missing a penalty in their Champions League tie with Bayern Munich, and the overriding feeling is that a player who cost £42.5m could do more. A 42-place fall on this list does not necessarily equate to a fall from grace but Özil will be under pressure to perform when he returns from the knee injury he suffered in October.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: David de Gea
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Unfairly written off by many fans and media pundits following a couple of high-profile mistakes upon his arrival at Old Trafford, the Spaniard must be revelling in seeing his detractors choke on their words as he delivers consistently excellent performances behind what currently passes for the Manchester United defence. De Gea travelled to the World Cup with Spain but did not feature, even if repeated blunders by Iker Casillas suggested that his understudy ought to have been first choice. Played the first of what should be many competitive internationals for his country in October, and kept a clean sheet.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Juan Cuadrado
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Cuadrado did not win as many headlines at the World Cup as his Colombia team-mate James Rodríguez but with three assists and a goal – a penalty against Japan – you can be certain the scouts took notice. A bewitching dribbler with a broad repertoire of feints and dummies, he beat his man more often than any other player in Serie A last season. The biggest question now is simply what position Cuadrado should be playing in. Fiorentina have used him everywhere from wing-back to centre-forward, a fact which reflects well on his versatility and work-ethic, but also hints at a failure to make any one position his own.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Jérôme Boateng
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Call it a triumph for one man’s ability to improve, or a damning indictment of Manchester City’s short-sightedness; either way, no one now doubts that Boateng is among the best defenders in Europe and, as such, unrecognisable from the error-prone player who left City to little fanfare in 2011. He underlined the progress he has made since then by scoring a winner in the Champions League against City for Bayern Munich, for whom he has become a crucial presence at centre-back. He helped Germany win the World Cup in the summer and his importance to that team is such that he is being tipped as a future captain of his country.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Miralem Pjanic
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The Bosnian playmaker is approaching his peak years and, if his current trajectory continues, they will be a joy to behold. Pjanic deserves his improved position for the way his beguiling, intelligent performances have translated themselves so consistently whatever the stage. Probably Bosnia’s best player during what proved a disappointing World Cup, he has been the creative brains for Roma too: every pass is laden with information; every shimmy and feint reveals a pocket of space or angle for release. Although he signed a new contract at the Italian club during the summer, Europe’s finest will surely come calling soon enough.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Pablo Zabaleta
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Mark Hughes did not get a lot of his signings right when he was Manchester City’s manager but they owe him one for introducing them to Zabaleta, who has become a cult hero with the club’s supporters. It felt as though his opportunities would be limited once City’s splurge began but his progress from a moderate Premier League right-back to a starter for Argentina in the World Cup final has been startling and proof of what can be achieved by players who are willing to work hard to reach the top. Zabaleta is a leader who plays with passion and intelligence – and even scores the occasional goal – and City love him for it.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Sergio Busquets
sheets.Sheet1.profile: 2014 was the first full year of Busquets’ career without a major trophy, and like his midfield colleagues Xavi and Andrés Iniesta, he failed to recreate his best performances for club or country. But whereas that duo’s careers are probably finally on the way down, Busquets has the capacity to recover, and he increasingly feels like the heartbeat of Barça’s midfield. His positional discipline and reliable distribution have always been assets, but he has become more penetrative with his passing, and wins possession increasingly high up the pitch. Even in a quiet year personally, he was still one of the best holding midfielders around.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Yacine Brahimi
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Porto showed typical shrewdness when they signed Brahimi from Granada last summer and they have been rewarded with some wonderful displays by a midfielder with rare technical gifts and speed, most notably in his match-winning performance against Athletic Bilbao and when he scored a spectacular Champions League hat-trick against Bate Borisov. The former France youth international declared his intention to play for the country of his parents’ birth in 2013 and was outstanding for Algeria at the World Cup. His creativity is one of the chief reasons why they are among the favourites for the 2015 Africa Cup of Nations.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Blaise Matuidi
sheets.Sheet1.profile: When Paris Saint-Germain bought Matuidi from Saint-Étienne in 2011 he was described as a replacement for Claude Makélélé, but perhaps a better word would have been upgrade. Matuidi is an able destroyer and a dynamic linker of play while also offering a thrust that makes him much more than a holding midfielder – he scored six goals and created another seven for his club last season. He has been inspirational in PSG’s last two titles and is a stalwart for France. “He scores goals, he defends, he keeps the ball,” says his PSG team-mate, Yohan Cabaye. “And when you see the way he runs, you feel obliged to bust a gut too."
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Radamel Falcao
sheets.Sheet1.profile: There was huge excitement when the Colombian signed for Manchester United on the last day of the summer transfer window: Falcao was regarded as one of the most formidable strikers in the world before joining Monaco from Atlético Madrid and the hope was that he would form a fearsome attacking trident with Wayne Rooney and Robin van Persie. Yet signing him was something of a gamble. A knee injury sustained in January kept him out of the World Cup and he has struggled for fitness and for game time at United, so sadly it is not a surprise to learn that the 28-year-old has slipped significantly down the rankings.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Marco Verratti
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A midfielder who, though too frequently booked, plays with a maturity that belies his 22 years of age, Marco Verratti has become such an asset to Paris Saint-Germain that they saw fit to improve and extend his already lengthy contract earlier this season in a bid to keep the vultures at bay. The most prolific passer of a footballer in Europe’s top five leagues, the Italian’s approach is more patient than that of his compatriot Andrea Pirlo, alongside whom he played in two matches during Italy’s decidedly inauspicious World Cup campaign. He is clearly relishing the more advanced role in which he plays his club football under Laurent Blanc.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Vincent Enyeama
sheets.Sheet1.profile: At one stage last season Enyeama kept 11 consecutive clean sheets for Lille, just short of the Ligue 1 record, then he put in several outstanding performances for his country at the World Cup. A wonderful shot-stopper with lightning reflexes and an excellent success rate in one-on-ones, he spreads confidence through his team with commanding interventions and vocal leadership. He is also very tidy with the ball at his feet, as might be expected from a player who has converted over 20 penalties in his career. Now 32, he is closing on 100 caps for his country and is recognised as the best goalkeeper in Africa, and among the finest in the world.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Edin Dzeko
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The Bosnian continues to have an uneven City career in which he can look average for a run of games before suddenly transforming into a world-beater. Big, solid centre-forwards with no particular turn of pace are virtually extinct at elite clubs, yet this scorer of “heavy” goals, to use David Platt’s term, continues to weigh in when most needed. Last season Dzeko registered nine goals in City’s last 11 matches to help push the team to the championship. Now, in Sergio Agüero’s absence, Dzeko – and his team – require a repeat performance.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Wilfried Bony
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A new entry on the list, Bony is arguably the finest striker who is not currently playing for one of the Premier League’s elite clubs. As dangerous in the air as he is on the ground and brilliant both at finding space in the area and holding defenders off before getting shots away on the turn, the Ivorian scored 37 goals in his final season for Vitesse Arnhem and then – after a £12m move to Wales – grabbed 26 in his debut year for Swansea, resuming his prolific ways, after a slow start, in this campaign. Bony also scored twice for the Ivory Coast at the World Cup and it is increasingly hard to see how Swansea can keep him for much longer.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Gonzalo Higuaín
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The summer of 2014 was painful for Higuaín, with a World Cup final defeat to Germany followed swiftly by a loss to Athletic Bilbao in Champions League qualifying. From standing on the brink of footballing immortality, he suddenly had nothing more to look forward to than a long Serie A campaign and Europa League football on Thursday nights. For a time it seemed his spirit had been crushed, as he turned in a string of listless performances at Napoli and failed to score a league goal until October. But lately he has been back in form, reminding us he can be one of the most lethal finishers on the planet.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: John Terry
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Arguably playing the best football of his career, the Chelsea captain remains a towering presence in what has been the best defence in the league over the past two seasons. His calm, reassuring performances alongside Gary Cahill in the heart of Chelsea’s back four led to calls for his return to the England squad prior to the World Cup, but Roy Hodgson remained unmoved. Slow on the turn, with a general lack of pace which forces him to sit deeper than ideal, Terry remains excellent in the air and is an astute reader of the game, whose leadership skills provide a calming influence on those around him.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Miroslav Klose
sheets.Sheet1.profile: It would have been easy enough for Klose to call time on his career in July. At 36 years old, he had just won the World Cup with Germany, becoming the tournament’s all-time leading scorer in the process. But, while the Poland-born striker did announce his retirement from international football soon afterwards, he still enjoys playing too much to give it up altogether. His legs cannot carry him through as many games as they used to, but he is still scoring for Lazio in Serie A and remains one of the most effective poachers on the planet, with an efficiency of movement that few players younger than him can equal.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Mario Mandzukic
sheets.Sheet1.profile: There is a rawness to Mandzukic that meant he was perhaps never the ideal fit for Pep Guardiola’s Bayern, although his energy in closing down opponents should not be underestimated. With Robert Lewandowski’s signing known well in advance, it was inevitable the Croat would be leaving the club in the summer, but he still finished as Bayern’s top scorer with 26 goals. He has maintained his form at Atlético as Diego Costa’s replacement, the highlight so far being his hat-trick against Olympiakos in the Champions League. Although he is yet to score, his leading of the line has been vital in Croatia’s fine start to Euro 2016 qualifying.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Gianluigi Buffon
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The critics will tell you that Buffon is starting to show his age but every time the chorus rises above a certain volume, he comes up with an emphatic riposte. His reflex stop from Koke during Juventus’s vital, goalless Champions League draw with Atlético Madrid in December provides a vivid recent example, but more impressive than any individual save is the player’s enduring consistency. Buffon kept out a higher percentage of the shots that he faced (81.1%) than any other goalkeeper in Serie A last season. Even as he approaches his 37th birthday, he remains an uncontested choice as Italy’s No1.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Jackson Martínez
sheets.Sheet1.profile: ‘Cha Cha Cha’ always had a lot to live up to in Portugal, inheriting the Porto No9 shirt previously occupied by his illustrious compatriot Radamel Falcao. He took up the baton without missing a beat, however, and had 77 goals in 111 matches by the beginning of December. His strength is complimented by his intelligence and invention. The failure to become a go-to for Colombia, even after Falcao’s injury, must hurt (although he scored twice against Japan in the World Cup) but he is a genuine leader for Porto, and has scored five goals in four Champions League starts this season to help propel his side into the last 16.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Antoine Griezmann
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Real Sociedad pulled off a coup when they signed this French prodigy as a 14-year-old. He made his debut in 2009, aged 18, though it took nearly five years for his performances at Sociedad to yield a first senior cap, which finally came in March. He went on to feature in all five of France’s matches at the World Cup, putting together an impressive audition to be Franck Ribéry’s heir, and convincing Atlético to spend £24m on him. “He is very clinical, scores a lot of goals and creates a lot of goals,” said Didier Deschamps. “He is equally comfortable on either side and through the middle. On top of that, he is tactically very aware.”
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Aaron Ramsey
sheets.Sheet1.profile: During the 2013-14 season the Welshman discovered goals. He might have scored a few before, he may fizzle out and score only occasionally in future, but during a wonder period he suddenly had a Billy’s Boots knack for goals. Although he missed the first three months of 2014 with a thigh injury he returned to score the most vital goal of all to win the FA Cup for Arsenal, crowning a turnaround from 2-0 down to 3-2 up against Hull with an instinctive stroke to flick the ball into the corner. Overall his tally of 16 goals from 34 club appearances last season underlined how he assumed a talismanic presence for Arsenal.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Hugo Lloris
sheets.Sheet1.profile: It is a wonder how the Frenchman manages to stay calm given the shambles that has often been providing him with paltry protection since the start of last season at White Hart Lane. Lloris, who captained France to the last eight of the World Cup, has spared Tottenham’s blushes on countless occasions in the past 18 months with his sharp reflexes and alertness. The way he puts off opposition strikers with his speed off his line makes him stand out. It is generally agreed that he deserves to play behind a better defence, so it may be difficult for Mauricio Pochettino to hang on to him beyond the end of this season.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Ezequiel Garay
sheets.Sheet1.profile: One of the best defenders at the World Cup, Garay built his reputation at Benfica after failing to establish himself at Real Madrid. He is as tough as they come – it was his challenge that knocked poor Christoph Kramer senseless during the World Cup final – but also has considerable finesse. After missing out on a quadruple with Benfica last season when losing the Europa League final on penalties, he joined André Villas-Boas at Zenit, after Manchester United inexplicably passed on his services, and has made an excellent start to his career in Russia.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Luiz Adriano
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Despite all his goals Luiz Adriano has never had a high profile in his homeland, which he left as a 20-year-old in 2007, though the five goals he scored against Bate Borisov in a Champions League game in October caught the eye (only Lionel Messi had scored so many in a single game in the history of the competition). Given how prolific he has been in the last couple of seasons and how much Brazil has suffered from the lack of a decent No9 – remember Fred? – it was even more surprising that he had never played for the senior Brazil side until last month, his first ever call-up coming two days after that demolition of Borisov.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Francesco Totti
sheets.Sheet1.profile: They say you can’t teach an old dog new tricks. Perhaps it is just a question of having the right motivation. Shortly before facing Roma at the Etihad this September, Manchester City’s Twitter account reminded the world that Totti had never scored a goal in England. A few hours later, the 38-year-old did exactly that, chipping Joe Hart and becoming the Champions League’s oldest-ever scorer in the process. He then went on to break his own record with another strike against CSKA Moscow two months later. With a contract running to 2016, you would not bet against him raising the bar again next year.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Steven Gerrard
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Luis Suárez and Daniel Sturridge were integral to Liverpool’s title challenge but no player exerted a greater influence on the 11-match winning run that brought the trophy within touching distance than the club’s captain. Converted into a holding midfielder, Gerrard excelled. His distribution, intelligence and nerveless penalty-taking looked to have ended his long wait for a first title but that costly slip against Chelsea marked the start of “probably the worst three months of my life” for England’s captain, continuing into a dreadful World Cup. So far this season he has struggled, and is unsure whether to extend his Liverpool career.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Dani Alves
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Injury precluded Dani Alves from being one of the unfortunate Brazilians who will forever be tainted by association by that World Cup humiliation at the hands of Germany, but it didn’t stop him from lambasting the “assholes” and “losers” who mocked his team-mates in the wake of the 7-1 thrashing. Despite endless rumours linking him with a move away from the Camp Nou, where Gerard Piqué was recently overheard informing him the pair “have many enemies”, the rampaging right-back, who is fabled for spending more time in the opposition half than his own, continues to be a regular in Luis Enrique’s side
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Gervinho
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Barely 18 months after his miserable final season at Arsenal Gervinho is now thriving at Roma, a key figure in a title-challenging team. He is quick to credit Rudi Garcia as the key component in this reversal of fortunes. Having previously worked with Gervinho at Lille, the Roma manager understands the player’s flaws – an erratic touch and lack of composure in front of goal – better than most, but chooses to focus on the positives instead. Gervinho continues to waste more chances than he should, but offsets this with the sheer volume of opportunities that he creates.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Mehdi Benatia
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Two transfers in two summers – from Udinese to Roma, then on to Bayern – summarise Benatia’s sudden transformation into an elite centre-back. The 27-year-old is physically impressive, but not dependent upon his strength because of his reading of the game. He’s perfect for Pep Guardiola, happy playing in either a three- or a four-man defence, and is comfortable enough in possession to start attacks, or combine with other defenders under pressure in deep positions. Morocco’s absence from the World Cup, and Benatia’s lack of major honours, means he remains underrated, but his stock will continue to rise.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Isco
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Despite initially finding opportunities limited at the Bernabéu after moving to Real Madrid from Málaga, this preposterously talented young midfielder has consistently impressed. He helped turn Real’s fortunes around against Atlético Madrid after coming on in the Champions League final in May, catching the eye with his particularly audacious twirling first touch in the opposition penalty area. A decent finisher blessed with excellent vision, close control and the ability to thread a pass through the eye of a needle, it is difficult to discern any weaknesses in the game of a 22-year-old with the world at his feet.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Henrikh Mkhitaryan
sheets.Sheet1.profile: An underwhelming year for Dortmund means Mkhitarayan hasn’t enjoyed a particularly sparkling year, but when on form the Armenian number ten remains extremely exciting. He specialises in finding space between the lines and arriving late in the box, and he has a very precise, deliberate style with his passes and shots. However, it was Mkhitarayan’s goalscoring ability from midfield which made him so valuable, and his efficiency in the final third has completely dried up. Jurgen Klopp has often deployed him in a deeper position than usual, but no goals or assists in his last 17 Dortmund matches summarises Mkitarayan’s struggles.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: José Callejón
sheets.Sheet1.profile: It has been an excellent year for the Napoli forward, who has made a prolific start to this season, including a run during Autumn of seven goals in as many league games. Callejón did not quite do enough to make the grade at Real Madrid but now, with the trust of Rafael Benítez, looks an altogether more fearsome beast and could be an important component of the post-World Cup Spain landscape too. He won his first cap in November and offers something different with direct running to go with adept close control and clinical finishing. He will be 28 in February, but there is a feeling that his best is yet to come.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Miranda
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Many people in Brazil and Europe were baffled by Miranda’s omission from the Brazilian World Cup squad, given that the defender’s keen reading of the game and rock-solid partnership with Diego Godín had been so important to Atlético Madrid’s journey to the Champions League final and the La Liga title. Further questions were asked after the shambolic 7-1 humbling by Germany and it comes as no surprise that Miranda has featured in every game for his country since the summer. Atlético will have been delighted to keep him last summer, but Miranda continues to be linked with a move to one of Europe’s elite clubs.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Iker Casillas
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Two errors in Spain’s infamous 5-1 World Cup defeat to Holland seemed to confirm impressions of Casillas’s decline, which had started to set in when José Mourinho cast him so firmly into the shadows during his time at the Bernabéu. Another error against Slovakia in a Euro 2016 qualifier caused further derision but this has already been one of his most successful years. How many people captain Real Madrid in a Champions League win against their city rivals, securing La Décima in the process? He has not had the easiest ride of late but has been a class act over 16 seasons, making more than 700 appearances
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Daley Blind
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Being voted the Eredivisie player of the year in May after helping Ajax to the title was an outstanding achievement by Blind, bearing in mind how unspectacular his job tends to be. That accolade was reward for his ubiquity, understanding and precision, attributes that made him a vital cog for his club. He performed the same role for his country as Holland finished third at the World Cup and Louis van Gaal was so impressed he paid £14m to bring him to Old Trafford, where he made a strong early impression before sustaining a knee injury while playing for his country in November that will rule him out until well into the new year.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: César Azpilicueta
sheets.Sheet1.profile: The right-back whose performances on the opposite flank convinced Chelsea they could dispense with Ashley Cole. Azpilicueta had been a fringe player, a back-up to Branislav Ivanovic, before being offered a chance when Cole suffered a rib injury in late 2013 and has been excellent ever since. Quick, defensively sound and decisive in the tackle, he was Chelsea’s find of last season and has resisted the challenge provided by the £15.8m Filipe Luís for his position this term. “A team of Azpilicuetas would probably win the Champions League,” says José Mourinho, “because football is not just about pure talent.”
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Jack Wilshere
sheets.Sheet1.profile: This is Wilshere’s first appearance in the Top 100 and for a while it seemed like this might be the year he started to fulfil his rich potential, with his impudent finishing touch to a mesmeric team move to score against Norwich City voted as the best goal of the 2013-14 Premier League season. Yet he has continued to be hampered by injuries, his form has wavered and he has failed to find a regular position at Arsenal, beginning on the bench when the club won the FA Cup final to end their nine-year wait for a trophy. He was peripheral to England’s World Cup flop, but impressed in the autumn qualifiers before his latest injury.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Héctor Herrera
sheets.Sheet1.profile: If plenty are bemoaning weary limbs and minds in the aftermath of a World Cup summer, Herrera is not one of them. His excellent displays with Mexico in Brazil have positively galvanised him for his sophomore season with Porto. The 24-year-old had endured a hugely disappointing debut season at the Dragão, underpinned by a red card after just six minutes of his Champions League debut against Zenit St Petersburg last October. This season, however, it’s clear to see why Porto toughed out protracted negotiations to get him, with his box-to-box power making him the natural successor to Lucho González.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Gerard Piqué
sheets.Sheet1.profile: It’s been a poor year for the elegant Barcelona centre-back who appears to have forgotten how to defend in the absence of his former partner Carles Puyol, who retired at the end of last season. Piqué was shown up badly during Spain’s World Cup humiliation at the hands of Holland and, amid rumours of a fraught relationship with his manager, Luis Enrique, has repeatedly been linked with a move away from Barcelona. The player himself insists he is content at the Camp Nou but he is reportedly teaching his two-year-old son seven languages, including Russian, English and Chinese, so he’s keeping his options open.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Enner Valencia
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A new entry, the striker was prolific for Pachuca in Mexico and then followed that up by being Ecuador’s only goalscorer at the World Cup, plundering three goals in the group stages. That caught the attention of the watching world and earned a move to West Ham and he has adjusted quickly to life in England and the Premier League, which is not always the case with South American players. Quick with the ball at his feet and also a genuine threat in the air, he wasted no time in making himself a favourite at Upton Park when he sent a scorching 25-yarder past the Hull City goalkeeper Allan McGregor on his first league start.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: David Luiz
sheets.Sheet1.profile: It’s hard to reconcile the disastrously-positioned defender who struggled in so many matches at the World Cup with the Roy of the Rovers figure who scored that beautiful quarter-final free-kick in the same tournament. Not everyone is a fan but certainly no current Brazilian player bar Neymar is quite as charismatic, and his compatriots somehow seem to like his madness. By spending an initial £40m, rising beyond £50m with add-ons, to bring him from Chelsea in the summer Paris Saint-Germain probably overpaid for him but Laurent Blanc insisted that “he’s a great defender, even if he takes some risks sometimes”.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Memphis Depay
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A newcomer to this list, the young PSV wide man impressed for Holland during the summer in Brazil, where he grabbed two goals in the group stages – becoming the youngest Dutchman ever to score in the competition – and also made the three-man shortlist for the World Cup’s Best Young Player award. The pacy left-winger’s good form has continued in the Eredivisie, making him a target for Manchester United and Southampton, who are both managed by famous compatriots. A player who attacks with intent from the flank, whilst comfortable cutting inside and taking on defenders, Depay is widely considered to be one of the brightest young talents in European football.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Daniele De Rossi
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A big fall for De Rossi, who is reportedly paid more than any other Serie A player but is not quite the dominant, all-action figure of several years ago. Still influential in last season’s outstanding Roma side, he has not been helped by injury and suspension this time around. De Rossi, who won his 100th cap for Italy in November in the 1-1 Euro 2016 qualifying draw with Croatia, is second only to Francesco Totti in Roma’s local hero stakes and remains a totemic figure at the Stadio Olimpico who channels that particularly Italian mix of aggression and intelligence. But time is running out if he is to translate that into a still-elusive Serie A title.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Rogério Ceni
sheets.Sheet1.profile: Outspoken, moody and egocentric, Rogério Ceni never set out to make friends, but has become enormously popular anyway. The goalkeeper, who turns 42 in January, announced his retirement earlier this year, as he had in 2012 and 2013, insisting that this time “I’m going to really stop” – only to once again be convinced to keep playing. He will try to further extend an outstanding record at both ends of the pitch (he scored his 120th goal in September, unsurprisingly a record for a goalkeeper). Ceni has so far featured in 1,117 games for the same club – also a record – and captained São Paulo in 866 of them (another).
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Radja Nainggolan
sheets.Sheet1.profile: A powerful all-round midfielder, Nainggolan has been in exceptional form for Roma, and was extremely unfortunate to be omitted from Belgium’s World Cup squad. But whereas many members of his country’s so-called golden generation endured a difficult 2014, this was the year Nainggolan emerged as a top-class player, following his move from Cagliari in January. Nainggolan can fill every possible midfield role – as you’d expect from someone who, unusually, idolised both Rino Gattuso and Ronaldinho as a teenager. That’s a neat summary:  he’s combative, energetic, and increasingly an attacking force too.
name: Footballer100 2014

sheets.Sheet1.name: Seydou Doumbia
sheets.Sheet1.profile: At club level, the 26-year-old has been prolific, carrying on the form he first showed at Young Boys since his move to CSKA Moscow in 2010. He scored 18 goals in 22 games as CSKA won a second successive Russian title last season and has banged in seven in 12 this campaign. He’s also impressed in European competition, scoring five in seven matches over the past two seasons – including both goals at the Etihad as CSKA beat Manchester City in the Champions League. Doumbia has found goals harder to come by at international level, but will fight it out with Wilfried Bony to lead the line for Ivory Coast at the Cup of Nations.
name: Footballer100 2014
